comment: /* Descriptive and Normative */ refine definitions of descriptive and normative senses

diff.*:
Line 18: Line 18:      
===Descriptive and Normative ===
 
===Descriptive and Normative ===
−
* In its descriptive sense, ''morality'' refers to [[Value (personal and cultural)|personal or cultural values]], [[code of conduct|codes of conduct]] or social [[mores]]. It does not connote objective claims of right or wrong, but only refers to that which is considered right or wrong. [[Descriptive ethics]] is the branch of philosophy which studies definitions of morality.
+
* In its descriptive sense, "morality" refers to [[Value (personal and cultural)|personal or cultural values]], [[code of conduct|codes of conduct]] or social [[mores]]. It does not connote objective claims of right or wrong, but only refers to that which is considered right or wrong. [[Descriptive ethics]] is the branch of philosophy which studies morality in this sense.
−
* In its "[[normative]]" sense, ''morality'' is a [[definition]] of right and wrong which excludes [[subjective]] opinion. [[Normative ethics]] is the branch of philosophy concerned with correctly choosing between such definitions.
+
* In its [[normative]] sense, "morality" refers to whatever (if anything) is ''actually'' right or wrong, which may be be independent of the values or mores held by any particular peoples or cultures. [[Normative ethics]] is the branch of philosophy which studies morality in this sense.
  +  
===Realism and anti-realism===
 
===Realism and anti-realism===
